Verse:
Self, self-possession, annihilation, permanence, denying existence, considering inferior to be superior,
Falsely claiming causality and path, are the intrinsic natures of the five views.
Discussion:
Due to the power of teachings, there are ignorant people who grasp at the five appropriated aggregates as self and self-possession. This view is called the view of the transitory collection.
Because of existence, it is called sa. KÄya means collection, which means aggregation.

That is to say, the one who grasps a self, in a single continuum or in many continuums, calculates that there is a self. All of these are not the body, because the body is not one.
Because such a view has as its condition the five aggregates, it is called the view of the five aggregates. This means that it has only the five aggregates as its object.

Do not say that because the self does not exist, the object of the cognition that grasps a self is nonexistent. Or, the substance of the self that is grasped by cognition does not not exist. If it were not so, then one would not establish the name â€œview of the five aggregatesâ€ in regard to the view that grasps as existent the aggregates that are grasped.

Grasping at annihilation and grasping at permanence regarding the matter of the self and what belongs to the self is called extreme view, because one falsely grasps at the extreme of annihilation and permanence.
In regard to the truths of suffering and so forth that actually exist, to give rise to views that deny their existence is called wrong view.
The five kinds of false views all turn upside down and should all be called wrong, but only the denial of existence is called wrong view, because the fault is too great.
For example, foul curd, bad grasping, and bad views, etc., are only depreciations, while the others are exaggerations.
To consider that which is inferior to be superior is called the view of holding to that which is inferior as supreme.

That which is contaminated is called inferior, because it is eliminated by the noble ones. To grasp that which is inferior as superior is called the view of holding to that which is inferior as supreme.
In reality, it should be established as the view of grasping, etc., but the word etc. is omitted, and it is simply called the view of holding to that which is inferior as supreme.
Or, because the view is superior, it is simply called the view. Because the view is the first to grasp other dharmas.
To consider that which is not a cause or a path to be a cause or a path, all of which are generally called the view of holding to a rule and ritual as supreme.
For example, MaheÅ›vara, time, nature, or others, which are not actually the cause of suffering, are falsely grasped as the cause.
There are two kinds of paths:
The path of superior rebirth and the path of decisive victory.
Various kinds of wrong practices such as throwing oneself into water or fire, which are not the cause of rebirth in the heavens, are falsely grasped as the cause, called the first path.
Only upholding precepts and rituals, the nature of a man, wisdom, etc., which are not the cause of liberation, are falsely grasped as the cause, called the second path.
Because they are like the past and so on, or because they are superior to mere precepts and observances, they are therefore called the grasping of mere precepts and observances.
You should know that the five views have these natures.

If one regards ÄªÅ›vara and so on, which are not causes, as causes, then this grasping of mere precepts and observances is deluded about the meaning of causes. Why is this view not eliminated by the path of seeing the truth of origination?
Verse:
Regarding ÄªÅ›vara and so on, which are not causes, one falsely grasps them as causes.
Because they arise from the inverted views of permanence and self, they are only eliminated by seeing suffering.

Discussion:ğŸ”½Regarding ÄªÅ›vara and so on, which are not causes, one falsely grasps them as causes. They are definitely unable to investigate profound principles, but only falsely regard the coarse fruits of the aggregates of ÄªÅ›vara and so on as permanent, unitary, and creators. This is the foremost, and one then grasps them as causes. Therefore, this grasping is eliminated by seeing suffering.

That is to say, the view of the aggregates as a self is the view of the aggregates as a self. Regarding the meaning of the fruit of suffering, one falsely grasps it as a self, so when one directly realizes suffering, the view of a self is eliminated.

The knowledge of nonself does not arise later, because if the view of a real self were eliminated by seeing the truths of origination, etc., the view of a real self would still be present in the continuity of one who has seen the truths of cessation and path, because the knowledge of nonself would not yet have arisen. This is because when one sees only dharmas, the view of a real self is eliminated.

The knowledge of nonself arises and the view of a real self is eliminated. However, the view of a real self has already conceived of a single self in the continuity of dharmas such as ÄªÅ›vara, and then next it grasps the extreme view of permanence in those dharmas in continuity.
For this reason, you should understand that the two attachments to the permanence and selfhood of dharmas such as ÄªÅ›vara are eliminated only by seeing the truth of suffering.
Therefore a verse says,ğŸ”½Before one truly sees suffering, one sees it as a self.
If one truly sees suffering, one does not see it as a self.

On the basis of this, the extreme view of annihilation at the end of cessation is already revealed, because the theory of nonself includes the correct view of annihilation, while the theory of self includes the extreme view of annihilation. Therefore, we know that the two views are both eliminated by the vision of suffering. When the impure activities of impermanence, etc., see the truth of suffering, the two views are extinguished.

The view that the cause of things is a self, etc., which is born from the two views, is also extinguished at the same time. Therefore it is said that the view that grasps a cause is eliminated only by the vision of suffering.
However, in the case of the view that a nonpath is a path, if it is strong, it is eliminated by the vision of the path.

Why is it not like the view that a self, etc., is a cause, and the view that suffering is a cause, which you admit is eliminated only by the vision of suffering and not by the vision of the origination of suffering? In the same way, you should admit that the view that a nonpath is a path and the view that suffering is a path is eliminated only by the vision of suffering and not by the vision of the path.
This objection is not reasonable, because the view that the truth of suffering is impermanent, etc., is not the antidote to that view.
If one holds that God, etc., are causes, one must have previously conceived of them as beginningless and endless, etc.

This cause is only eliminated by the path of vision of suffering, because the idea of impermanence, etc., is the antidote to the idea of permanence, etc. When one sees suffering and impermanence, etc., one is not able to eliminate the grasping of non-path as path, therefore the grasping of path is not eliminated by the path of vision of suffering.
This also refutes the view that it is eliminated by the path of vision of the origin, because seeing the cause, etc., is not the antidote to that.

That is to say, when one sees the cause, etc., of the origin, one is not able to eliminate the grasping of non-path as path. One is only able to eliminate the grasping of non-path as path when one sees the path, etc., of the truth of the path. Therefore the grasping of path should be eliminated by the path of vision of the truth of the path.

If this is so, then this grasping of non-path as path must be eliminated by the path of vision of the origin and cessation, because it is like wrong views that deny the true path, and then immediately grasp that as being able to attain purity.
This grasping of precepts and rituals is admitted to be eliminated by the path of vision of the truth of the path.

Thus, if one denies the truths of origination and cessation, and later still believes that they can obtain purity, then the two types of adherence to particular views as supreme should be eliminated by the path of insight into the truths of origination and cessation.

This objection is not reasonable, because the substance of the two types of adherence to particular views as supreme is not established. The two types are: 1) taking that which is not a cause to be a cause, and 2) taking that which is not a path to be a path. If one believes that the false view that denies the truth of origination can obtain purity, then this view has no function of eliminating origination and therefore should not arise, because there is no mind that believes in the existence of a cause.

Also, because there is no separate substance of suffering and its cause, the aggregates of self, etc., should also be denied. If one believes that the false view that denies the truth of cessation can obtain purity, then this view has no function of realizing cessation and therefore should not arise.
How can one deny the truth of cessation and still believe that the means of realizing cessation is not useless?
Thus, the substance of adherence to particular views as supreme is not established, and therefore it is not a real difficulty.
How is it not a difficulty?

The substance of the clinging to mere precepts and ritual as essential that is to be eliminated by the path of insight would not exist, because after the view that denies the truth of the path, one would not be able to grasp that there is a path.
That is, if one denies or doubts the path of liberation through wrong views or doubt that have the path as an object, how can one grasp that this can bring about eternal purification?

The substance of this clinging to mere precepts and ritual as essential is not nonexistent, because there is the clinging to the wrong views that deny the path as being able to bring about eternal purification, because it is grasped as being a correct understanding.
That is, one first stores in the mind other paths of liberation, and later grasps the wrong views that deny the true path as a correct understanding.

What is meant by correct? They consider the denial of and doubt about the true path of liberation to be nonerroneous, and because it is correct, they grasp it as the cause of purification. Consequently, this becomes the substance of clinging to mere precepts and ritual as essential.

The other paths of liberation that are stored in the mind are not objects of the clinging to mere precepts and ritual as essential that is to be eliminated by the path of insight, because this clinging has only its own class of dharmas as objects.
The path has many types, and there is no error in principle.
For this reason, the author of the treatise says:

If one denies the true path of liberation and falsely grasps other pure causes, then one would grasp other means of attaining purity, not wrong views and so forth. This would be the dharmas eliminated by seeing the path.
This reasoning also does not hold, because they have not fully understood the meaning of the Abhidharma school.
If that is so, then the substance of the grasping of precepts and vows eliminated by seeing the truth of cessation should also be established, because it is the same as the path.

That is to say, there are those who first keep in their minds other places of liberation, and later grasp the wrong views that slander true liberation as correct understanding, because they are correct they are grasped as pure causes, as before they should be established as the substance of grasping precepts and vows.

There is no such principle. The general idea of liberation is that it is permanent and tranquil. Grasping the mind that slanders it as a pure cause is not established, because the principle is not established, like grasping the substance of nirvana as real or unreal.
If one seeks the means of liberation, one must definitely believe that there is liberation.
Those who definitely believe that liberation exists must admit that its nature is eternal quiescence.
If one does not admit this, one should not seek it.
Just as in the true teaching, although there are differences in regarding nirvana as real or unreal, they agree that it is eternal and quiescent. Therefore, both views are seen as faults.

In the same way, if one has in mind another aggregate of liberation, one must generally believe that nirvana is eternal quiescence. For this reason, one does not take the view that slanders liberation to be a correct understanding. Therefore, clinging to precepts and vows that is eliminated by the path of seeing definitely does not exist.
Moreover, although Devadatta generally admits that nirvana is eternal quiescence, he separately believes that the five dharmas are the path of liberation, apart from the eightfold noble path.
The principles believed by non-Buddhists should also be the same.
Therefore, there is slanderous wrong views regarding the eightfold noble path that are taken to be correct understanding, but there is none regarding the slander of cessation.

That is, the substance and mode of activity of the precepts and observances are different from the holy path, but there is no difference in the substance and mode of activity of nirvÄá¹‡a and quiescence. Therefore, non-cessation is the same as the path.

Other masters say:ğŸ”½There is an interpretation that the wrong view that takes the path as not the path is the adherence to rules and observances, because it does not say that this is the truth of the path of cessation.

Even if one adheres to the truth of cessation and says that it is not the truth of cessation, it is not established as the adherence to rules and observances that takes wrong views as the truth of the path.
That is, it is definitely unreasonable to adhere to it as the truth of cessation that is eliminated by the path of insight, because it is just eliminated.
If one adheres to it as the path of another nirvÄá¹‡a, then one substance would have two natures, because one sees it and obtains the expedient for it.

Also, there is no meaning of taking as an object the dharmas of another category that are eliminated by the path of insight into cessation. However, those non-Buddhists must certainly imagine the differences in other suffering as liberation.

Now we must consider the view that non-liberation is liberation. This means either taking precepts and observances as the cause of liberation, or taking the view of self as able to realize liberation. Are these eliminated by seeing suffering or by seeing the path?
If it is said that both are eliminated by seeing suffering, then that eliminated by seeing the path should definitely be nonexistent.
Or it should be said that there are other causes, etc. Why are these two views eliminated by seeing suffering, while the rest are eliminated by seeing the path?
If it is said that both are eliminated by seeing the path, it should be explained why.
When seeing the path, one is unable to understand those objects, or to understand their intrinsic nature, or to eliminate their objects.

Or the principle of universal knowledge should be destroyed, that is, if the proclivities eliminated by seeing the path are able to take as objects those eliminated by seeing suffering, who would prevent the destruction of the universal knowledge and establishment?

For example, when the knowledge of suffering has already arisen in the stage of realization of the truths, and the knowledge of the cause has not yet arisen, that which is to be eliminated by the view of suffering is still bound by the bonds of that which is to be eliminated by the view of the cause. Although it has already been permanently eliminated, the complete knowledge has not yet been established.

In the same way, when the knowledge of cessation has already arisen and the knowledge of the path has not yet arisen, that which is to be eliminated by the view of suffering is still bound by the bonds of that which is to be eliminated by the view of the path. Although it has already been eliminated, the complete knowledge has not yet been established.
However, this is not accepted. The principle should be explained.
Our school says that both are eliminated by the view of suffering. As the Abhidharma treatise says:
There are some non-Buddhists who give rise to such views and establish such doctrines, saying:

If there is a person or pudgala who upholds the precepts of a cow, the precepts of a deer, or the precepts of a dog, they will attain purity, liberation, deliverance, and forever transcend suffering and reach the place beyond suffering and pleasure.
Such and other types of grasping at non-causes as causes should all be known as the grasping of precepts and practices, eliminated by the view of suffering, as explained in detail by them.
For what reason is this also eliminated by the view of suffering?
Because they only see those that are eliminated by the path of seeing, such as the precepts regarding cows, etc., and only consider gross effects to be their causes.

Based on this, we refute the objection raised by the Sutra master, that there is the fault of over-extension in confusing the truth of suffering, because all defiled passions that take contaminated [dharmas] as objects are confused about suffering, because not all defiled passions that take contaminated [dharmas] as objects take suffering as their object.
How can there be the fault of over-extension?

It is not admitted that both are eliminated by the path of seeing suffering. If eliminated by the path of seeing the truth of the path, then they absolutely do not exist. There are two types of views that take what is not the path to be the path: one takes precepts and observances, etc., as the path; the second directly confuses the path.

Those that take precepts and observances, etc., as the path contradict the faith that understands the path. Their power is not as great as those that directly confuse the path. Those that take precepts and observances, etc., as the path have extremely coarse aspects, do not follow closely, and their intention is not firm. With little effort, they are immediately eliminated.
Those that directly confuse the path are the opposite of this.
Based on this, one should understand that there are two types of distinctions in the views that take what is not the path to be the path:
The first is eliminated by seeing suffering, and the second is eliminated by seeing the path.
As explained above, the delusions of permanence and self arise. Are there only these two kinds of delusions?
No, there are four kinds of delusions in total.

The first is the delusion of permanence regarding impermanence, the second is the delusion of pleasure regarding suffering, the third is the delusion of purity regarding impurity, and the fourth is the delusion of self regarding non-self.
What are the natures of these four delusions?
Verse:
The intrinsic natures of the four delusions are derived from the three views.
Only by inverting and exaggerating are conceptualization and thought influenced by the power of views.
Commentary:

The intrinsic natures of the four delusions are established based on the three views. That is to say, within the view of extremes, only the view of permanence is taken as the delusion of permanence. Within the view of grasping at views, grasping at the notion of pleasure and purity is taken as the delusion of pleasure and purity. Within the view of grasping at the perishable collection, only the view of self is taken as the delusion of self. This is the position of one master.
However, the VibhÄá¹£Ä has a definitive interpretation: among the twelve views distinguished in the various schools, only two and a half are the substance of perversions.

That is, the view of the existence of a self, the entire view of grasping at the superior, and a part of the view of grasping extremes that grasps at permanence. The two views of annihilation and permanence are mutually contradictory in their mode of activity, and therefore they can be said to have separate substances.
Those who hold the view of a self grasp at the self as having sovereign power over that which is grasped as mine. This view of a self turns on two aspects.
Isn't it the case that all passions are perversions? Therefore, all should be perversions, not just the four.
No. The characteristics of perversions are established differently.
What are the characteristics of perversions?
They are endowed with three causes.
What are the three causes?
They are one-sided perversion, the nature of investigation, and false superimposition.
The word increase also shows that the substance is superior.

Other passions do not have these three causes. The view of grasping rules and ritual as being paramount is not a complete perversion, because it is possible to be free from the passions of the realm of desire by means of this view, and because one can obtain purification by means of a little discrimination.

The view of annihilation and false views are not false additions, because these two views occur in the mode of negating existence. The view of grasping dharmas as paramount of other schools is not superior, and the remaining passions are not speculative in nature.
For these reasons, there are only four kinds of perversions, and not any others.
Isnâ€™t it the case that the scriptures speak of twelve kinds of perversions? A scripture says,
There are four kinds of perverted views and four kinds of perverted thoughts.
There are also perverted views and perverted thoughts with regard to suffering, impurity, and non-self.
No, because thought and conceptualization are not speculative in nature.
They are called perversions because they are associated with views and have the same characteristics as views.
However, feeling, etc., are not called perversions, because they have a separate cause.

When one generates views of permanence, etc., with regard to the impermanent, etc., one necessarily grasps the characteristics of permanence, etc., with regard to the object. That which grasps these characteristics is conceptualization, not the other mental activities. Therefore the name â€œpervertedâ€ is established on the basis of conceptualization, not on the basis of feeling, etc.

Also, the wisdom that cures the perversions is also called conceptualization, because the scriptures say that the practices of impermanence, etc., are the conceptualizations of impermanence, etc. This is because wisdom and conceptualization are close associates, and the name is established by association. This is not so for feeling, etc.
The mind is called â€œpervertedâ€ because it is perverted by the power of conceptualization and because it is perverted by the characteristics of the grasped object. A scripture says,
â€œThe mind leads the world and causes it to be tossed about in the flood of the passions and to drift on the waves of the five destinies.â€
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas say,
Only conceptualization and mind can be called perversions, because this is universally recognized.
The world universally recognizes that conceptualization and mind are perverted, but not that feeling, etc., are perverted, and therefore the scriptures do not say that they are.
Therefore conceptualization and mind are called perversions because they are perverted by the power of the perversions of views. This is not so for feeling, etc.
The Sthavira says,
What is the reason that the perversions are only three in number and not more or less?
Because only that much is necessary to constitute the three inversions.

The three inversions are as follows: the inversion of conceptualization is included in conceptualization, the inversion of thought is included in consciousness, and the inversion of view is included in the aggregates of form and volition.
It cannot be said that feeling is also included in the inversions, because it arises with contact as its cause and is experienced as appropriate.
Are there no other mental factors such as attention included in the aggregate of volition? Why are they not inversions?
It is not so. It is only because of their inversion that thought, conceptualization, and view are made to constitute the substance of the inversions. Therefore a scripture says:
All the innumerable evil and unwholesome dharmas arise with irrational thought as their root, and so on, up to the point where all are born of attention, and contact is their source.

This proves that the inversions of conceptualization, thought, and view are born of the ignorance and contact that are irrational, and that because of their inversion, they constitute the substance of the inversions.
We now observe that what you have said is internally contradictory, and therefore we definitely know that it is not the meaning of the scriptures.
If conceptualization, thought, and view arise from improper attention, etc., they are inverted because they are born from inversion.
But feeling arises from improper attention, etc., so why is it not inverted?
If feeling arises from inverted attention, etc., and is not inverted, then conceptualization, thought, and view should not be inverted, because there is no separate cause.
It is also said that feeling cannot be included in inversion, because it arises from contact as a cause, as appropriate to its experience.
But why should conceptualization not also be inverted? It also arises from contact as a cause, as appropriate to its conceptualization.

Since it is said that conceptualization, etc., are inverted because they are born from the contact of ignorance, how can it be proven that feeling is included in inversion, because it arises from contact as a cause, as appropriate to its experience?
Because feeling also arises from the contact of ignorance.
Therefore, their statement that only these three are inverted, and inversion is only three without increase or decrease, is meaningless.

Also, if conceptualization, etc., are mistaken because of the power of mistaken views, then mistaken views themselves should be mistaken, but this is not admitted. Therefore the opinion of the other schools is based on their own ideas.
Or, even if it is admitted that conceptualization, etc., are mistaken, still they should not be called the three mistaken views, and this contradicts the sÅ«tra.

If you say that although conceptualization, etc., are mistaken because of the power of views, still the sÅ«tra only speaks of the three mistaken views of thought and conceptualization, not of the mistaken views of feeling, etc., because of a special reason,
we reply that our school also has a special reason for not calling conceptualization, etc., mistaken views. Therefore conceptualization, etc., definitely are not mistaken views.
Or, if the other dharmas are mistaken views, this contradicts the sÅ«tra.
This is not reasonable, because there is no similarity.

That is, in our school, although conceptualization, etc., are mistaken because of the power of views, still we call them mistaken views only in the case of thought and conceptualization, not in the case of feeling, etc., because of a special reason.

However, the view that is the cause of the error is rightly called an inverted view. In the same way, in your school, the attention that causes the mind and mental activities to be inverted should be called an inverted view.
Also, just as in our school, the substance of thought, etc., is not inverted, but is only hypothetically called inverted because of the view,
so in your school, thought, etc., are not really inverted, but are hypothetically called inverted because of the power of attention.

The real name for inversion should refer to the attention that is the cause of inversion, and it is not proper to call things that are not inverted inverted because of the power of other things that are not inverted.
Also, why do you not admit that the power of thought is able to cause attention to become the substance of an inverted view?
It is only because of the power of deluded grasping of characteristics that there arises the non-logical attention that is innate. Therefore a scripture says:
Because of the power of grasping characteristics, it causes evil and unwholesome dharmas such as craving to arise.
Also, a scripture says:
Because of the confusion and inversion of thought, the mind is burned with fever.
It does not say that mental heat arises from improper attention.

Moreover, it should be that by the power of the most inverted dharmas, the nature of conceptualization and mind is also called inverted. Reason is not that the inversion of attention is superior to conceptualization, etc. How can it only be said that by the power of attention, conceptualization, etc. become inverted, and not that conceptualization, etc. can cause attention to become inverted?
Therefore, what they say relies only on their own grasp.

Moreover, the sÅ«tras also say that desire is the basis of dharmas, or that afflictions and ignorance are the roots. How is it that they do not say that by their power, they can also cause conceptualization, etc. to become inverted, but only say that inversion is accomplished by attention?
Therefore, one should know that the establishment of the essence of inversion based on the Abhidharma principle is the most excellent.
To what are these inversions eliminated?
The proponents of the correct theory say:

Only the view of suffering is eliminated, because the four inversions of permanence, etc., only occur in relation to suffering, because the understanding of impermanence, etc., only arises in relation to suffering, and because the views of permanence, bliss, self, and purity should not be abandoned when the truths of origination, cessation, and path are seen.
If this is so, then it contradicts the scriptures, treatises, and correct principles.
First, it contradicts the scriptures, because a sutra says:

If there are many learned noble disciples who truly see and know the noble truth of suffering, and likewise truly see and know the noble truths of origination, cessation, and path, then at that time those noble disciples will have completely eliminated the inversions of thought, mind, and view that regard what is impermanent as permanent, and so on, and so forth.

If the four inversions are only eliminated by seeing suffering, then the sutra should not say that they are completely eliminated when one truly sees and knows the truths of origination, cessation, and path.
Moreover, a sutra says:
If one hears the Tathagata's teaching of the four noble truths of suffering, origination, cessation, and path, then one can permanently eliminate the four inversions of permanence, etc.
It is not that all errors are eliminated only by seeing suffering. The Buddha can be said to eliminate them. The other three views realize the origin of suffering, etc., and are not their antidotes.
Moreover, SubhÅ«ti told PratibhÄnamati:
Because there is confusion and error in thought, therefore your mind is scorched and heated;
Far away from those thoughts, when craving ceases, the mind is purified.
As for contradicting the treatise, the Abhidharma-Å›Ästra says:
Among these four errors, how many kinds have been eliminated by the stream-enterer, and how many have not been eliminated?
One should say:
All have been eliminated.

If the four errors are eliminated only by seeing suffering, then those who follow faith and those who follow the teachings will also have already eliminated them. Why is it said that only the stream-enterer has eliminated them?
As for contradicting correct reasoning, if the noble ones who have not yet eliminated desire eliminate the notions of pleasure and purity, how can they give rise to desire and greed?
Our school does not violate any of the three [points of criticism].

As for the meaning of the first sutra, when the noble disciples attain insight into the four noble truths, the four inverted views accumulated since beginningless time are already permanently severed. It cannot be concluded from this that each of the four inverted views is severed by seeing the four truths.

It has already been established that the two views of self and extremes are severed only by seeing suffering. The inverted views of permanence and self are identical to the two views of self and extremes. How then are the inverted views of permanence and self severed by seeing the origination, etc.?
However, in this sutra it is said that they are permanently severed by one who has fully seen the truths. What contradiction is there?

As for the second sutra, there is no contradiction. The Blessed One did not teach the four noble truths only for the sake of severing these four kinds of inverted views. He did so in order to bring about the ultimate cessation of all suffering. However, some, upon hearing this, permanently sever the four inverted views in accordance with the power of the antidotes. What contradiction is there?
This is indeed the correct principle. Therefore that sutra says:
When the Buddha taught this Dharma, it was for the sake of the ultimate cessation of all suffering,
Some, having heard this, know the truth of impermanence, suffering, no-self, and impurity.
